sen.j: 政官（じょうかん・上官）とは、律令制の太政官の事務方官人の総称である。
sen.e: Jokan (spelled as "政官" or "上官") is the collective term for government officers who mainly engaged in clerical work in Daijokan (Grand Council of State) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of a centralized government based on Ritsuryo Code.)

Jokan (written as "上官" or "政官") is the collective term for government officers who were mainly engaged in clerical work in the Daijokan (Grand Council of State) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of a centralized government based on the Ritsuryo Code).
sen.cmt: spelled as→written as; fixed grammar
sen.e: "Jokan" (written as "上官" or "政官") is the collective term for government officers who were mainly engaged in clerical work in the Daijokan (Grand Council of State) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of a centralized government based on the Ritsuryo Code).
sen.cmt: 統一リスト（その他 2009/6/29）の指示により、Jokan にダブルクォーテーションを追記しました。

sen.j: 一般的には、「三局」と称された少納言局・弁官局・外記局を率いる少納言・弁官・外記と三局に属した史 (律令制)・史生以下の下級官人（反対に考えると、公卿・議政官を除く全ての太政官官人）を指す。
sen.e: Generally Jokan indicates government officials, who were Shonagon, Benkan and Geki, the heads of Sankyoku (three bureaus of Shonagon bureau, Benkan bureau and Geki bureau respectively) and Shi (an official in charge of records) and Shisho (an official doing miscellaneous duties about documents), the lower ranking Kanjin (government officials) belonging to Sankyoku, in other words Jokan indicates all the officials of Daijokan (Ground Council of State) except Kugyo (the top court officials) and Giseikan (Legislature.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Jokan was a broadly used term to indicate government officials such as the Shonagon, Benkan and Geki, who were the three directors of the Sankyoku (an assortment of three bureaus: the Shonagon bureau, Benkan bureau and Geki bureau, respectively), the Shi (an official in charge of records), the Shisho (an official in charge of miscellaneous documents) and lower ranking Kanjin (government officials) affiliated with the Sankyoku, or in other words, Jokan indicates all of the officials of the Daijokan except the Kugyo (top court officials) and the Giseikan (Legislature).
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: Jokan was a broadly used term to indicate government officials such as the Shonagon (lesser councilor of state), Benkan (controller) and Geki (secretary of the Grand Council of State), who were the three directors of the Sankyoku (an assortment of three bureaus: the Shonagon bureau, Benkan bureau and Geki bureau, respectively), the Shi (an official in charge of records), the Shisho (an official in charge of miscellaneous documents) and lower ranking Kanjin (government officials) affiliated with the Sankyoku, or in other words, Jokan indicates all of the officials of the Daijokan except the Kugyo (top court officials) and the Giseikan (Legislature).
sen.cmt: 少納言、弁官、外記にそれぞれ意味を追記しました。Shonagon (lesser councilor of state)Benkan (controller)Geki (secretary of the Grand Council of State)原文の「が、」→「。」に変更

sen.j: 一方、詔勅・宣命などの公文書作成にあたる内記（中務省内記局）を含む用例や外記局を除いて少納言・弁官のみを指す用例、反対に外記及び史以下の官人に限定する用例なども存在する。
sen.e: However, there are other examples that Jokan included Naiki (secretary of the Ministry of Central affairs) in charge of producing Shochoku (imperial rescript) and Senmyo (imperial edict), that it only indicated Shonagon and Benkan and that it only meant Kanjin or lower Kanjin on the contrary.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On the other hand, there are also examples contradicting the term as stated above, such as one that includes the post of Naiki (Secretary of the Ministry of Central Affairs) in charge of producing official documents like Shochoku (imperial rescripts) and Senmyo (imperial edicts) as a Jokan; an example that Jokan only indicates the Shonagon and Benkan but not the Geki; and a contrasting example showing that the term is limited to Kanjin lower in rank than Geki and Shi.
sen.cmt: lengthened a bit to clarify positions; fixed grammar
sen.e: On the other hand, there are also examples contradicting the term as stated above, such as one that includes the post of Naiki (Secretary of the Ministry of Central Affairs) in charge of producing official documents like Shochoku (imperial rescripts) and Senmyo (imperial edicts) as a Jokan; an example that Jokan only indicates the Shonagon and Benkan but not the Geki; and a contrasting example showing that the term is limited to Kanjin lower in rank than Geki and Shi.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: ただし、後世においては「政官、上官也、云外記・史也」（『色葉字類抄』）などと最後の用例で用いられることが多くなる。
sen.e: However, in the later days the word Jokan was often used in the sense of the last one of the expressions mentioned above, like the one in "色葉字類抄 (Irohajirui-sho," Kango-Japanese Dictionary in Heian Period, in which it says that "政官、上官也、云外記・史也,"which means "Jokan are Geki and Sho."
sen.cmt: 「政官、上官也、云外記・史也」の正確な読み方はわかりませんでした。
sen.e: In later years, however, the word Jokan was often used in the same sense as described in the last example, as illustrated by examples from the "Irohajirui-sho"(Kango-Japanese Dictionary from the Heian Period) where it is explained that Geki and Shi were referred to as Jokan.
sen.cmt: I understand that the translator for translation #1 didn't understand the way to read "史也" but I am guessing that the "sho" is a typo and should be "shi" since it would be consistent with the other readings; fixed grammar
sen.e: In later years, however, the word Jokan was often used in the same sense as described in the last example, as illustrated by examples from the "Irohajirui-sho"(Kango-Japanese Dictionary from the Heian Period) where it is explained that Geki and Shi were referred to as Jokan.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: なお、四辻善成の『河海抄』には、「政官」は“太政官被官”に由来し、宛字として「上官」を用いたと記されている。
sen.e: In addition, according to "河海抄" (Kakaisho Commentary) by Yoshinari YOTSUTSUJI, Jokan comes from Daijokan-hi-kan (a government official directly reporting to Daijokan) and gives it a phonetic equivalent "上官" (jokan.)

In addition, according to a Kakaisho Commentary by Yoshinari YOTSUTSUJI, the term originated from "Daijokan-hi-kan" (a government official reporting directly to the Daijokan, written as “太政官被官”) which contains the phonetic equivalent of "Jokan," sometimes written as "上官."
sen.cmt: The kanji related to "jokan" are a bit confusing, but because the article itself seems unsure as to how to read the characters I felt it was important to keep them; eliminated other kanji; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: In addition, according to "Kakai-sho Commentary" by Yoshinari YOTSUTSUJI, the term originated from "Daijokan-hi-kan" (a government official reporting directly to the Daijokan, written as “太政官被官”) which contains the phonetic equivalent of "Jokan," sometimes written as "上官."
sen.cmt: 用語集の表記に従い、a Kakaisho Commentary を"Kakai-sho Commentary" に修正しました。

sen.j: また、洞院実煕の『名目鈔』には、「政官」に“ジヤウグハム”と読み仮名を振っている。
sen.e: Also in "名目鈔" (Myomoku-sho) by Sanehiro TOIN, the pronunciation to the Chinese characters "政官"is written as "ja-u-gu-ha-mu."

sen.j: ただし、律令格式には採用されていない語であり、元来は貴族社会における俗語のようなものであったと考えられている。
sen.e: But Jokan was not adopted as an official word in the Rittsuryo-Kyakushiki (Laws of codes and ethics under Ritsuryo-system) and it is assumed that the word was originally a kind of one of the slang words in the noble society.

Jokan was never adopted as an official word in the Ritsuryo-Kyakushiki (Laws of codes and ethics under the Ritsuryo system) however, and it is assumed that it was a slang word used within noble society.

sen.e: Jokan was never adopted as an official word in the Ritsuryo-Kyakushiki (Laws of codes and ethics under the Ritsuryo system) however, and it is assumed that it was originally a slang word used within noble society.
sen.cmt: 「元来は」訳漏れのためoriginally を追記して訳漏れ対応しました。

sen.j: 太政官符・宣旨などの公文書作成や太政官における公事・儀式の先例校勘・記録作成、人事案件の処理などの実務にあたり、太政官における事務方を担当した。
sen.e: Jokan dealt with practical works such as producing official documents of Daijokanpu (official documents issued by Daijokan) and Senji (Imperial Decree) etc., comparing and examining the precedents and producing records for Kuji and Gishiki (political operations and ceremonies of the Imperial Court), and handling personnel affairs, and as Jokan also took the charge of Kansei (Imperial meeting at Daijokan agency) and Gekisei (meeting at Geki agency), it increased its role and especially the status of Geki and Shi much improved.

Jokan dealt with practical works such as producing Daijokanpu (official documents issued by the Daijokan) and Senji (Imperial Decree), comparing and examining the precedents and producing records for Kuji and Gishiki (political operations and ceremonies of the Imperial Court) and handling personnel affairs.

sen.cmt: 用語集の表記に従い、Imperial Decree を imperial decree に修正しました。

sen.j: 官政・外記政において結政を担当するようになるとその役割が増大し、特に外記及び史の地位が大きく上昇した。
sen.e: As Jokan also took charge of Kansei (Imperial meetings at a Daijokan agency) and Gekisei (meetings at a Geki agency), it increased its role and and the status of Geki and Shi in particular much improved.

sen.j: 後に外記の上首（筆頭）を局務（きょくむ）、史の上首を官務（かんむ）と呼んで公卿・議政官を除く太政官官人の筆頭的地位を占める事となる。
sen.e: Later, Joshu (the head) of Geki was called Kyokumu (the chief secretary of the Daijokan) and Joshu of Shi called Kanmu and they came to hold a kind of the highest position in Daijokan Kanjin except Kugyo and Giseikan.

Later on, the Joshu (director) of the Geki was called Kyokumu (Chief Secretary of the Daijokan), the Joshu of the Shi was called Kanmu and these two came to hold the highest positions in the Daijokan Kanjin aside from the Kugyo and Giseikan.
